ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SCHOOLS IN KAMPONG KEMBANGAN
(Progress and performance)


    1. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education if he will report on the progress and performance of the primary and secondary schools in Kampong Kembangan Constituency based on the PSLE and GCE 'O' results, respectively; and to state what measures, if any, the Ministry may take to bring about

Column: 310

further improvements of the schools' progress and performance.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon)(for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the PSLE and 'O' level results of the primary and secondary schools in Kampong Kembangan Constituency for the past three years are attached (Cols. 395 - 396) to my reply and I shall hand this over to the Member for Kampong Kembangan afterwards.
attached - PSLE RESULTS (1981-1983), GCE 'O' LEVEL RESULTS (1980-1982) (Cols. 395 - 396)


    Many measures have been and are being taken by the Ministry of Education to improve the textbooks, teaching methods,

Column: 311

audio visual aids and so on in our schools. The Member for Kampong Kembangan would be aware that they have been discussed and made public through the monthly Schools Council meetings. I would be happy to provide the Member with more details of these Ministry projects.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister of State have any programme to visit my Constituency and to meet the principals and teachers of the secondary and primary schools in my Constituency to discuss matters of common interest? If so, when will that visit likely be?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, I would welcome an invitation, but it is a matter of time before I can comply. We have over 450 schools, and I have been visiting some schools.

LANGUAGE PROGRAMMES IN CHINESE, MALAY AND TAMIL
(Measures to enrich)


    2. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education what measures are being taken or will be taken, in view of the rapidly declining enrolment in non-English streams, to enrich the language programme in Chinese, Malay and Tamil and to promote their study in schools in order that they be given their proper place and that future generations of Singaporeans are not culturally uprooted.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, for the vast majority of our pupils, the learning of the mother tongue as a second language is not difficult. Last year, the passing rate for CL2, ML2 and TL2 at PSLE was around 97%. At 10, level, the corresponding passing rate was around 87%. Therefore, there is no decline in the interest or ability of our students to study the mother tongue in the vast majority of cases.

    Nevertheless, my Ministry has taken a number of steps to further improve the teaching of the mother tongue and to promote its use in our schools.

Column: 312



    The main improvement is in the new textbooks, audio visual materials and teaching methods which have been and are being developed by CDIS. Project teams have been formed for CL2, ML2 and TL2. For example, the teaching of CL2 in primary schools has been significantly improved by the use of the new CLIPS materials for primary schools. The CLIPS materials are a major departure from earlier materials. Apart from being more interesting, the materials also give greater emphasis to listening, speaking and reading skills in addition to writing skills. Studies by CDIS and the Institute of Education show that, on the whole, pupils taught with the CLIPS approach score about 12% higher than those taught by non-CLIPS methods. The CLIPS series has reached Primary 6 level this year. Similar projects are in progress for secondary CL2 materials and for the ML2 and TL2 courses.

    The second language textbooks are not just grammar books. They also contain many stories taken from the classics which are intended to impart moral and cultural values. As much as 77% of their contents are on moral and cultural topics. To ensure that the language is relevant to daily life, the textbooks also contain topics related to social and economic aspects of life,

    To encourage the use of the mother tongue, all moral education classes are taught in the mother tongue in the primary schools. At the secondary level, moral education classes are taught either in English or in the mother tongue. Recognizing that there is a shortage of supplementary reading materials in the mother tongue languages, CDIS as well as private publishers are producing a growing list of new titles. Schools have been encouraged to organize their own "Speak Your School Languages" campaigns, including the mother tongue. I can therefore assure the Member for Boon Teck that my Ministry is aware of the need and is making every effort to encourage the teaching and the use of the mother tongue in our schools.

Column: 312

CHINESE LANGUAGE 2 AT 'O' LEVEL
(Standard of Pass grade)


    3. Dr Koh Lip Lin asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of

Column: 313

Education (a) what is the standard of a passing grade in Chinese Language 2 (CL2) at 'O' level and whether a student who has passed CL2 at 'O' level be able to read Chinese newspapers and general books and write reasonable Chinese; (b) what steps his Ministry has taken, with the introduction of a new national stream education system, to ensure that the quality of teaching and the standard of CL2 will not decline in future; (c) whether there is a minimum number of hours assigned to the teaching of CL2 in schools; and (d) whether his Ministry will consider replacing the names CL2, Malay Language 2 (ML2) and Tamil Language 2 (TL2) with CL, ML and TL, respectively.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, I want to thank the Member for Nee Soon for raising specific questions concerning the teaching of CL2. This gives me the opportunity to clear some doubts which have arisen in the media concerning the standard of CL2. But before I answer his questions, I want to take this opportunity to clear up two misconceptions which have arisen since the recent announcement that by 1987, all our schools will be of the national type teaching ELl and mother tongue as second language.

    The first misconception is the belief by some that the mother tongue, especially Chinese, is now no longer important. This is not so. CL2 is important. The bilingual policy remains unchanged. CL2 will continue to be given due weightage at PSLE and 'O' level for progress into secondary and Pre-U levels. At the NUS, students who are admitted without the pre-requisite of D7 in CL2 will have to pass a Chinese proficiency examination before they are allowed to graduate.

    The second misconception is that the termination of the Chinese medium stream by 1987 means that the future of Chinese language in Singapore is in doubt. This again is not so. The bilingual policy will ensure that Chinese is taught and learnt to the same level as it is today. Over the past decade, the majority of our school leavers have been through the bilingual system. Today, mote people than ever before are bilingual, especially the

Column: 314

younger generation. Let me quote some statistics from the 1980 census. For those aged 40 and above, only 7% are literate and bilingual in English and Chinese. For those between 30 and 39 years of age, 19% are bilingual. For those between 15 and 29 years of age, 35% are bilingual. Between the 1970 and 1980 census, the total percentage of Singapore Chinese who are bilingual rose from 11.8% to 29.6%, an increase of 2,3-fold. Thus, the number who are bilingual is growing steadily each year.

    I would now like to turn to the specific questions that the Member for Nee Soon has asked. A student who has completed CL2 at Sec 4 would have mastered about 3,000 characters. This should readily enable him to read the daily newspapers and general books, to discuss general topics in Chinese, and to write letters and short essays.

    As I mentioned in my reply to the Member for Boon Teck, my Ministry has taken a number of measures to ensure that the teaching of CL2 is improved. The standard of CL2 is carefully specified in the CL2 syllabus and in the new textbooks produced by CDIS. The syllabus prescribes a minimum of 3,000 characters and 200 idiomatic expressions that must be learnt by a student by the time he reaches Sec 4. The 'O' level CL2 examination is set and moderated by an independent panel from the Chinese Studies Department of NUS to ensure that the standard is maintained.

    The number of periods given to CL2 in primary and secondary levels is also prescribed. In primary schools, it is 8 to 10 periods per week depending on the level, while in secondary schools, it is 6 periods per week. Schools are, however, given some latitude to adjust the number of periods up or down by one period per week depending on the particular need of individual classes in the school. Thus, for example, many schools run extra remedial classes for their weak pupils. Extra Chinese language exposure time is also given to the pupils through subjects such as moral education and art and craft.

    The Member for Nee Soon has asked whether the suffix "2" could be dropped from CL2, ML2 and TL2. For the next few

Column: 315

years, there will still be many students in our schools doing L1 and L2. Dropping the suffix at this stage may create confusion among the schools. At a later date, if necessary, it would be possible to do so.

MR PHEY YEW KOK
(Steps to secure return to Singapore to stand trial)


    4. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs what further progress has been made by the police to obtain or secure the return to this country of the former President of the National Trades Union Congress to stand trial upon the charges instituted against him and on which he jumped bail or have the police closed their file on this and given up all efforts to find him and bring him back.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to inform the Member for Anson that the warrant of arrest against Phey Yew Kok is still very much in force. Phey Yew Kok remains on the wanted list of all Interpol affiliated countries, and the alert for his arrest on sight is still on.

    The Police and CPIB are in constant contact with the Interpol authorities in an effort to locate Phey Yew Kok. To-date they have not received any information on his present whereabouts.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question for the Minister. Would the Minister recall that when I raised this question some months ago, his answer was that Mr Phey Yew Kok was in hiding in one of our neighbouring countries and, for some reason or another he could not tell this House which neighbouring country it was. May I know what is the position now? Is he still in one of these neighbouring countries, or has he disappeared from one of these neighbouring countries?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have said in my reply, we have no information of his present whereabouts - the word is "present" whereabouts.

Column: 316

As for the question which I was asked last year, I think it was exactly 12 months ago, the answer is that he has disappeared from that country. Perhaps, as a result of the debate in Parliament, he might have taken note of it and made himself scarce.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister state quite clearly to this House or outline the various steps that have been taken by the police to trace this man, instead of contenting himself with a general answer saying that all steps are being taken? May this House be informed of the precise steps that have been taken by the police?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, as a lawyer, the Member for Anson should know that if a wanted man is in one of the countries outside Singapore, the Singapore Police has no jurisdiction to go to that country and make the arrest, they have to depend on the cooperation of the police force of that country.

    I have stated quite clearly in my answer that the way to go about it, ie, to get the cooperation and help of the police force of other countries to apprehend a wanted criminal, is to contact Interpol and Interpol can get the countries which are affiliated to Interpol to help in the apprehension of the wanted criminal.

    What more does the Member for Anson expect us to do? I have stated in my reply that we are in constant contact with the police authorities of the affiliated countries where we think he might be taking refuge.

     Mr Ho See Bong (Khe Bong): Could the Minister tell this House how strong is the possibility that the fugitive MP has disappeared from our neighbouring country because of our debate in this Parliament about his running away from Singapore?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: I cannot say how strong it is. But what I can say is that there is a possibility because my reply states that we have information that he is taking refuge in a neighbouring country. So any intelligent or not-so-intelligent fugitive will take note of it and make himself scarce.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: As I said, would the Minister recall his statement to this House about this man hiding in a neighbouring country? We all know we are surrounded by ASEAN countries. Is the Minister saying

Column: 317

that he is not getting cooperation from these governments in an attempt to trace this man?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have never stated that we are not getting cooperation. I stated that we have to depend on their cooperation. And even if the authorities of the countries want to cooperate, it is not easy to apprehend a fugitive from justice.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: If I wrote to Interpol, would the Minister agree to Interpol releasing to me all the efforts that have been made by them on behalf of the Singapore Police Force? If I wrote to them, would he agree with that?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, we do not represent Interpol. And we also do not control the freedom of action of the Member for Anson. So my answer is quite obvious. He can write to Interpol if he likes. How can the Government of Singapore or the Singapore Police Force interfere with his freedom of action?

     An hon. Member: He wants your approval!

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Does he need my approval?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: All I want is a straight answer from the Minister. May I say to Interpol that the Government of Singapore has no objections to their disclosing to me all efforts that they have made on behalf of the Government to trace this man? May I have a straight answer to that question?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, before I can say yes, I certainly would like to see the contents of that letter. In what way is the letter phrased? I repeat my answer - I have no control over the actions of Interpol, neither have I control over the actions of the Member for Anson. Is that not an obvious and clear answer?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: We are now getting some straight answers from the Minister. He says that if I tell him what I want to know, then he will consider giving me a reply. What I want to know from Interpol is: what steps have they taken over the last four or five years on behalf of the Singapore Government to trace this man, and would they make public to me what has

Column: 318

been done? Would the Minister say whether he will object to them disclosing all this to me?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: If those are the words which are recorded in Parliament, I would say that I have no objections.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: He has no objections. Thank you.

OWNERSHIP/RENTAL OF HDB FLATS BY SINGLE PERSONS


    5. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for National Development if he will ask the Housing and Development Board to allow single persons to continue to rent or own HDB flats when the nucleus family no longer exists because of the death of the only other person forming the family nucleus.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Under the Housing and Development Board's current policy, a single person who survives the death of the other members of his family nucleus must include a relative or any other person as an authorized occupier if he wishes to retain his flat. Sufficient time is given for this condition to be satisfied. The HDB has to follow this policy in view of the high demand for flats. In land-scarce Singapore, it is also not possible for the HDB to provide a flat for each single person.

    8. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Minister for National Development what is the progress of the development of the park along Telok Blangah Heights.

DEVELOPMENT OF SENTOSA ISLAND
(Upgrading of facilities and attractions)


    9. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry if the Minister is satisfied with the progress of the development of Sentosa Island as a resort for Singaporeans and tourists; whether there are any plans to further upgrade the facilities and attractions and, if so, when these plans will be implemented.

     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Dr Wong Kwei Cheong) (for the Minister for Finance and Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, the progress made in developing Sentosa as an island resort for Singaporeans and tourists is in my view satisfactory. Since 1972, about $69 million has been spent by the Sentosa Development Corporation on developing facilities on the island. New attractions that have been added to the island in the last three years include the Musical Fountain, the Monorail System, Rasa Sentosa and the lnsectarium.

    The facilities at Sentosa are popular with Singaporeans and tourists. In 1980, 974,000 visited Sentosa. The number in 1983 was 1,367,000. There are plans by the Sentosa Development Corporation to upgrade the existing attractions and facilities. The Sentosa Wax Museum is being expanded to include a new section featuring the early pioneers of Singapore. The Musical Fountain will be improved. Some $1.9 million will be spent between now and mid-1985 on improving the swimming lagoon. There are also plans to upgrade Fort Siloso and the ferry terminal at the World Trade Centre. In addition, the Corporation is actively negotiating with private investors to develop a family entertainment park, resort hotels and an oceanarium.

TOA PAYOH BUS INTERCHANGE/FEEDER SERVICE SYSTEM
(Steps to improve)


    10. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the Acting Minister for Communications (a) whether he is aware that the recently introduced bus interchange and feeder service system in Toa Payoh housing estate, which is

Column: 321

operationally more efficient to the bus company, is not well received by commuters because they have not only to pay more but also to take a much longer time than before to reach their destinations; and (b) what steps are being taken or will be taken to improve the situation.

     The Acting Minister for Communications (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): The new feeder bus system in Toa Payoh was introduced after extensive surveys showed that it would provide a better bus service to the majority of residents in the estate.

    These surveys showed that the number of people who benefit from the change clearly outnumber those adversely affected - by about 4 to 1.

    The new system is also more efficient than the old one. Previously, buses had to make extensive loopings of as many as 10 km within Toa Payoh, prior to proceeding to its destination. This meant higher fares and an additional 15 minutes of travel for commuters. With the introduction of the feeder bus system, these extensive loopings have been minimized, enabling SBS to put on more buses into its trunk services. More than 95% of the trunk services serving Toa Payoh have peak frequencies of about 10 minutes compared with less than 73% before.

    The feeder bus service has also been successfully tried and tested in other HDB estates such as Bedok, Ang Mo Kio, Clementi, Telok Blangah, Tampines, Hougang, Jurong and Woodlands.

     Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Sir, is the Hon. Minister aware that, after the implementation of this new scheme, the majority of commuters have to wait double the time and to pay double fares?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe the figures that the Member for Toa Payoh has given are erroneous, when he talks about the majority of people having to pay double fare and to wait double the time.

     Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee: The Hon. Minister has not gone down to the place. I went down there on three mornings and I interviewed a number of commuters. All of them complained to this effect.

Column: 322



     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, careful surveys are currently being conducted to ensure that the situation operates the way it is designed to. We are aware that, because of the introduction of three primary schools in the Toa Payoh area, the traffic flow has not been as free flowing as we would like it to be. However, I dispute his figures that the majority are paying double the fare and waiting double the time.

     Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee: Another supplementary question, Sir. Is the Minister prepared to conduct another survey?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the surveys are being conducted routinely all the time.

ADVANCE ISSUE OF MOTOR VEHICLE REGISTRATION BOOKS
(Measures to prevent abuse)


    11. Mr Lim Boon Heng asked the Acting Minister for Communications what were the reasons for giving out new motor vehicle registration books in advance to certain motor vehicle trading companies; whether this has led to any abuse and, if so, what measures have been taken to prevent recurrence of such abuses.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the new motor vehicle registration books are given to motor vehicle trading companies in advance to expedite the registration process.
